Puerto Vallarta

Where mountain jungle meets sparkling bay — Mexico's most charming Pacific paradise

Quick Facts About Puerto Vallarta

Best Time to Visit
November - May
Average Temperature
26°C / 79°F
Known For
Malecón, Sunsets & LGBTQ+ Friendly
Airport Code
PVR

About Puerto Vallarta

Puerto Vallarta offers the rare combination of a genuine Mexican town with world-class resort amenities. Nestled between the Sierra Madre mountains and Banderas Bay, this Pacific gem features cobblestone streets, a famous malecón boardwalk, thriving arts and culinary scenes, and a welcoming atmosphere that has made it Mexico's most beloved beach destination.

Neighborhoods in Puerto Vallarta

Explore the unique character of each neighborhood and find the perfect area for your stay.

  • Puerto Vallarta

    {{#if this.vibe}}

    Vibe:

    The heart and soul of Puerto Vallarta. Cobblestone streets, the best restaurants, vibrant LGBTQ+ nightlife, Playa Los Muertos beach, and authentic Mexican charm. Where most visitors spend their time.

  • Puerto Vallarta

    {{#if this.vibe}}

    Vibe:

    The original downtown area surrounding the Church of Guadalupe and main plaza. More local than the Romantic Zone, with traditional shops, markets, and the northern Malecón.

  • Puerto Vallarta

    {{#if this.vibe}}

    Vibe:

    Strip of large resorts and hotels north of downtown along the main road. Good beaches, all-inclusive options, but requires taxi to reach downtown attractions.

  • Puerto Vallarta

    {{#if this.vibe}}

    Vibe:

    Upscale area with yacht marina, golf course, and luxury resorts. Quieter and more planned than other areas, with excellent marina-side dining.

  • Puerto Vallarta

    {{#if this.vibe}}

    Vibe:

    Exclusive hillside neighborhood south of the Romantic Zone with stunning ocean views, private villas, and small cove beaches. Very peaceful and scenic.

{{/if}}

Day Trips from Puerto Vallarta

Explore the surrounding region with these popular excursions.

  • Puerto Vallarta

    {{#if this.distance}}

    Distance:

    Bohemian surf town with colorful streets, laid-back atmosphere, excellent seafood, and beginner-friendly waves. The hippie counterpart to polished Vallarta.

  • Puerto Vallarta

    {{#if this.distance}}

    Distance:

    Charming colonial mining town in the mountains, frozen in time. Cobblestone streets, traditional haciendas, excellent coffee, and cool mountain air.

  • Puerto Vallarta

    {{#if this.distance}}

    Distance:

    Protected islands with the famous Hidden Beach, blue-footed boobies, and excellent snorkeling. Access is controlled to protect the ecosystem.

  • Puerto Vallarta

    {{#if this.distance}}

    Distance:

    Remote beach village accessible only by boat, with no cars or roads. Waterfalls, pie ladies, hammocks, and a taste of old Mexico.

  • Puerto Vallarta

    {{#if this.distance}}

    Distance:

    Exclusive resort peninsula with world-class surfing, luxury hotels, and beautiful beaches. Home to the Four Seasons and St. Regis.

{{/if}}

Practical Information

Frequently Asked Questions About Puerto Vallarta

Is Puerto Vallarta better than Cancún?
Puerto Vallarta offers a more authentic Mexican experience with its traditional downtown, while Cancún has a purpose-built Hotel Zone. Vallarta has better dining, arts scenes, and LGBTQ+ nightlife. Cancún has calmer Caribbean beaches and larger resorts. Vallarta attracts couples and LGBTQ+ travelers; Cancún draws more families and spring breakers. Both are excellent—it depends on your priorities.
Is Puerto Vallarta LGBTQ+-friendly?
Yes, Puerto Vallarta is one of Latin America's most LGBTQ+-friendly destinations. The Romantic Zone has numerous gay bars, clubs, hotels, and beaches (Blue Chairs area). The annual Pride celebration in late May is one of Mexico's largest. The city warmly welcomes LGBTQ+ travelers year-round with a vibrant, accepting community.
When is the best time to visit Puerto Vallarta?
November to May offers dry, sunny weather with average temperatures around 26°C (79°F). Whale watching peaks December-March. The rainy season (June-October) brings afternoon showers, higher humidity, but also lower prices and fewer crowds. Hurricane risk is low but possible September-October.
Is Puerto Vallarta safe for tourists?
Puerto Vallarta is considered one of Mexico's safest tourist destinations. The Romantic Zone, Malecón, and hotel areas are very safe to walk day and night. Use normal urban precautions: avoid isolated areas late at night, don't flash expensive jewelry, and use trusted transportation. Most visitors have wonderful, trouble-free experiences.
Is the water safe to swim in Puerto Vallarta?
Most Puerto Vallarta beaches are safe for swimming, though Pacific waters can have stronger waves and currents than the Caribbean. Popular safe beaches include Playa Los Muertos in the Romantic Zone and hotel zone beaches. Always check conditions, watch for flags, and swim near lifeguards when available.
How do I get from the airport to downtown Puerto Vallarta?
The airport (PVR) is about 20 minutes from downtown. Options include: official airport taxi ($25-35 USD—fixed rates posted at taxi booth), private transfer ($35-50 USD pre-booked), or Uber (cheaper but must walk outside airport arrivals). Many hotels offer shuttle service. Renting a car is convenient for exploring but not necessary.
How many days should I spend in Puerto Vallarta?
5-7 days is ideal to enjoy the beaches, explore the Romantic Zone and Malecón, take a day trip (Sayulita, Marietas Islands), enjoy the food scene, and perhaps add whale watching or zip-lining. With 3-4 days you can still see the highlights, but you'll want to return.
When is whale watching season in Puerto Vallarta?
Humpback whales visit Banderas Bay from November through March to breed and give birth. Peak season is January-February when calves are born and whale activity is highest. Tours depart daily during season, lasting 3-4 hours, with high success rates for sightings.
What is the Malecón in Puerto Vallarta?
The Malecón is Puerto Vallarta's famous mile-long oceanfront boardwalk, running along the bay from downtown to the Romantic Zone. It features remarkable sculptures by Mexican and international artists, restaurants, bars, and street performers. It's the soul of Vallarta, especially beautiful at sunset.
Do I need a car in Puerto Vallarta?
You don't need a car if staying in the Romantic Zone or downtown—everything is walkable or a short taxi/Uber ride. A rental car is useful for day trips to Sayulita, San Sebastián, or exploring the coast. Taxis, Uber, and local buses provide affordable transportation around town.
